intro: Acronema commutatum, commonly known as the narrow-leaved madder, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and opposite, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, white to pinkish flowers arranged in clusters, which bloom in the summer months. Its roots contain a red pigment called rubia, which has been historically used in dyeing textiles. Acronema commutatum thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
